SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Content: There are 4 times as many fish as there are frogs in a pond. There are 32 fish.
Which statement is true?

SubTopics: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Content: The measure of ∠P is 12°.
problems/NMG4M/media/2a.jpg
Which of these is the BEST estimate of the measure of ∠Q?

SubTopics: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
Content: Lisa read for 1/4 of an hour.
Which equation can be used to find s, how many seconds Lisa read?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.
Content: Which number is a prime number AND a factor of 56?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: Which fraction is equal to 9/12?

SubTopics: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.
Content: This subtraction problem is missing a digit.
problems/NMG4M/media/6a.jpg
Which digit belongs in the box to make the difference true?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: Macy made this model to help show the quotient of 2,850 ÷ 6.
problems/NMG4M/media/7a.jpg
THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the value of k in the model?
What is the quotient of 2,850 ÷ 6? Explain how the model is used to find the answer

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: A map with five roads is shown.
problems/NMG4M/media/8a.jpg
How many angles on the map appear to be acute angles?

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Content: Sofia is solving this word problem.

:box:Lincoln Elementary School has a mathematics club and a science club.

	• There are 30 students in the clubs total.

	• A student can only be in one club.

	• Twice as many students are in the mathematics club as are in the science club.

How many students are in the science club?
Which solution is correct?

SubTopics: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.
Content: Which equation shows the total amount of water, in cups, that can be put in all the jars that hold exactly 1/4 cup?

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: What is the difference between the amount of water the largest jars hold and the amount the smallest jars hold?

SubTopics: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Content: Jack used base-ten blocks to represent a number.
He used:

:ibox:• 5 ones

• 3 thousands

• 20 tens
What number did Jack show?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.
Content: Gary claims that he has listed all of the factors of 28 and 66, as shown.
Which of the following describes the changes Gary needs to make to his lists to make his claim correct?

A.Choice: add 7 to the list of the factors of 28 and add 33 to the list of the factors of 66

B.Choice: remove 3 from the list of the factors of 28 and remove 4 from the list of the factors of 66

C.Choice: add 7 and 21 and remove 4 from the list of the factors of 28; add 33 and remove 3 from the list of the factors of 66

D.Choice: add 7 and remove 3 from the list of factors of 28; add 6 and 33 and remove 4 from the list of factors of 66

SubTopics: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Content: The fourth-grade students at a school are having a pizza party. They need to know how much pizza the school should order for the party.

:ibox:• There are 113 fourth-grade students.

• Each student will get 2 slices of pizza.

• Each pizza costs $7.

• There are 8 slices in each pizza.
THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Write an equation that can be used to find s, the number of SLICES of pizza the school needs to order. Be sure to solve your equation.
Write an equation that can be used to find p, the number of PIZZAS the school needs to order. Be sure to solve your equation. Explain how you found your answer.

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Content: Two fraction models are shown.
problems/NMG4M/media/15a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: 7/8 < 8/10 because there are a greater number of equal parts in the model for 8/10.

B.Choice: 7/8 < 8/10 because a greater number of parts of the whole model for 8/10 are shaded.

C.Choice: 7/8 > 8/10 because a greater number of parts of the whole model for 7/8 are shaded.

D.Choice: 7/8 > 8/10 because a greater part of the whole model for 7/8 is shaded.

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Content: A store owner ordered 12 times as many small posters as large posters. She ordered 48 large posters.
How many small posters were ordered?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Content: An area model is shown.
problems/NMG4M/media/17a.jpg
Which of these is NOT represented in the area model?

SubTopics: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Content: Tanya made a pattern. All the numbers in her pattern can be divided by 3 evenly.
Which could be Tanya's pattern?

SubTopics: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.
Content: Which sentence is true about all rhombuses?

D.Choice: All sides must be different lengths.

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.
Content: This table shows the distance Kim jumped on each of six jumps.
problems/NMG4M/media/20a.jpg
What is the shortest distance Kim jumped?

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: Charisse made this shape by tracing a rectangle and a right triangle.
problems/NMG4M/media/21a.jpg
How many right angles are shown in Charisse's shape?

SubTopics: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Josh walks 3 miles each week. This week he walks 3/8 of a mile on Monday, 9/8 of a mile on Wednesday, and 5/8 of a mile on Thursday.
Which equation can Josh use to find m, the fraction of a mile he needs to walk the rest of the week to walk a total of 3 miles?

SubTopics: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.
Content: which number is the value of the 4 equal to ten times the value of the 4 in 14,111?

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Select the TWO shapes that have the same number of lines of symmetry.

SubTopics: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
Content: Kennan ran 5 kilometers. He incorrectly stated that he ran a total of 500 centimeters.
THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Why is Kennan's statement incorrect? Explain how you know.
How many centimeters are in 5 kilometers? Use words or numbers to explain your answer.

SubTopics: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
Content: Sylvia is painting a square-shaped wall. Each side of the wall has a length of 12 feet.
Which expression could be used to find the area of the wall?

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Content: It takes Josh 24 minutes to walk from his house to the school. It takes him 8 minutes to walk from the school to the park.
How many times longer does it take him to walk from his house to the school than from the school to the park?

SubTopics: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: Four students are solving this problem.
:box:The sum of two fractions is 2. The difference between the two fractions is 12. What are the two fractions?
Alice says the fractions are 4/2 and 1/2 because 4/2 = 2.
Bob says the fractions are 1/4 and 1 3/4 because the sum is 2.
Cora says the fractions are 1 3/6 and 6/6 because the difference is 1/2.
Darius says the fractions are 1 2/8 and 6/8 because 1 + 2/8 + 6/8 = 1 + 1 and 10/8 - 6/8 = 4/8.
Which child is correct?

SubTopics: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Content: Isla makes a pattern that starts at 5 and uses the rule “Multiply by 10.” Isla says that 550 will be a number in the pattern.
Which statement explains whether Isla is correct?

A.Choice: She is incorrect because the last digit in each number is a 5.

B.Choice: She is incorrect because only the first digit in each number is a 5.

C.Choice: She is correct because all of the numbers have only 5s and 0s.

D.Choice: She is correct because all of the numbers after the starting number end in 0.

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.
Content: The shaded parts of these models represent two decimals.
problems/NMG4M/media/30a.jpg
problems/NMG4M/media/30b.jpg
Which of these correctly compares the decimals shown in the models?

SubTopics: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
Content: Which numbers, when rounded to the nearest thousand, become 38,000? Select the TWO correct answers.

SubTopics: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: On Saturday, Katherine's Pie Shop sold 100 pies. This table shows the types and numbers of pies sold that day.
problems/NMG4M/media/32a.jpg
THIS PROBLEM HAS THREE PARTS.
What fraction of the pies sold were either blueberry or strawberry? Use words or numbers to explain your answer.
What fraction of the pies sold on Saturday were NOT apple? Use words or numbers to explain your answer.
Katherine calculated that 28/100 of the pies sold represented two types of pie.
Which types of pie could this fraction represent? Use words or numbers to explain your answer.

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: Miss Manning has a 10-pound block of clay that she cuts into pieces. She gives different weights of clay to 10 students. The line plot shows the weight of the clay she gives to 9 of the students.
problems/NMG4M/media/33a.jpg
Miss Manning gives the rest of the clay to the last student. What is the weight, in pounds, of the clay she gives to the last student?

SubTopics: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Content: A zoo has four giraffes. Their weights are given in this table.
problems/NMG4M/media/34a.jpg
The zoo gets a new giraffe that weighs two thousand, three hundred eight pounds.
Which giraffe has a weight closest to the weight of the new giraffe?

SubTopics: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.

Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: What is the missing fraction in this equation?

SubTopics: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.
Content: Four shapes are shown.
problems/NMG4M/media/36a.jpg
Brenna says the shapes all have at least two right angles. Then she realizes there are more ways the shapes are alike.
Which is NOT a way the shapes are alike?

A.Choice: They all have at least two pairs of perpendicular sides.

B.Choice: They all have at least two pairs of parallel sides.

SubTopics: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Content: Angle G is measured by a protractor, as shown. 90
problems/NMG4M/media/37a.jpg
What is the measure of angle G?
